exampleRoute.title: Karlsruhe ‚áÑ Zierow
exampleRoute.subtitle: 14 days ‚Ä¢ approx. 1,495 km ‚Ä¢ Slow travel with 5.5 t & dog
exampleRoute.lead: A calm, dog-friendly round trip with clear stages, fixed stops, and plenty of buffer for breaks.

ruleNotice.title: Important for 5.5 t
items: Observe truck overtaking bans and speed limits.
Motorways: 100 km/h only with approval, otherwise 80 km/h; rural roads max. 80 km/h.
Start on June 4, 2026 is Corpus Christi ‚Äì expect heavy morning traffic.

items.title: Stage 1: Karlsruhe ‚Üí Fulda/Rh√∂n area
items.route: A5 to Hattenbacher Dreieck, then toward Fulda.
items.pause: After ~1.5 h near Alsfeld for a dog walk.

items.title: Stage 2: Fulda area ‚Üí Magdeburg/Elbe area
items.route: A7 / A4 / A71 north. The Harz bypass is often calmer than the A7 Kassel hills.
items.pause: Near Sangerhausen or south of Magdeburg.

items.title: Stage 3: Magdeburg area ‚Üí Perleberg
items.pause: Short day ‚Äì plenty of time for Perleberg.

items.title: Stage 4: Perleberg ‚Üí Zierow
items.route: Final easy stretch to the campsite.

items.title: Stage 5: Zierow ‚Üí L√ºneburg Heath (Uelzen area)
items.route: B208 / B4 southbound (slow travel through the countryside).
items.pause: Good stops at farm shops or field paths.

items.title: Stage 7: Harz ‚Üí Spessart/Main
items.pause: Lunch stop at service areas with truck lanes.

items.title: Return ‚Ä¢ Harz
items.name: Campingplatz Am Brocken
details: In the heart of the Harz

outward.title: Outbound
items: Magdeburg waterway crossing: canal bridge over the Elbe

return.title: Return
items: Brocken hike or Brocken railway (dogs with muzzle)

items.label: Navigation
items.value: Use a camper GPS with vehicle dimensions (L: 7.2 m ‚Ä¢ H: 3.2 m ‚Ä¢ 5.5 t), e.g. TomTom Go Camper or Garmin.

items.label: Waste
items.value: Clesana toilet = residual waste. Greywater disposal available at all listed sites.

items.label: Fresh water
items.value: Large tank; refilling possible at each station.

items.label: Emergency
items.value: Mark veterinary clinics along the route in advance (e.g. Magdeburg, L√ºneburg).

items.label: Fuel
items.value: Truck stops are cheaper than motorway service areas. Use truck lanes if car pumps are too tight.

items.label: Groceries
items.value: Look for large parking lots in commercial areas (e.g. Kaufland, Globus).

items.label: Apps
items.value: Clever Tanken, Park4Night (filter >7 m, dog friendly), Promobil Stellplatz-Radar, NINA alerts.

items.label: Budget
items.value: Approx. ‚Ç¨1,200‚Äì1,500 for fuel, pitches, food, and entry fees.

items.label: Sustainability
items.value: Solar & Clesana mean no chemicals. Dispose bags in residual waste and support local farm shops.

items.label: Health
items.value: Tick protection for the dog is essential in June; keep the vaccination record handy.

items.label: Best time
items.value: June is ideal: long days, Baltic Sea around 15‚Äì17 ¬∞C.

items.label: Checklist
items.value: Long CEE adapter cable, water hose + watering can, heavy-duty leveling ramps.

items.label: Tires/backup
items.value: Carry a tire repair kit for trucks/RVs.

items.label: Self-sufficient
items.value: 600W solar / 600Ah / Clesana allow flexible site choice.

items.label: Wild camping
items.value: Prohibited in Germany and strictly enforced in protected areas.

items.label: Rest break
items.value: One-off overnight on parking lots is tricky with 7.2 m length ‚Äì use official pitches.

items.label: Options
items.value: Landvergn√ºgen or farm stays are good spontaneous alternatives.

items.label: A7 outbound
items.value: Detour via B27 (Fulda ‚Üí G√∂ttingen) ‚Äì scenic but slower.

items.label: Hamburg on return
items.value: Bypass Hamburg widely to the east (Uelzen/B4), avoid the Elbtunnel.

whatIs.title: An intelligent assistant for your motorhome routes.
whatIs.prec1: Artificial Intelligence (like ChatGPT) is great, but it needs precise instructions (prompts) to deliver truly usable results.
whatIs.prec2: Camping Route is a pure frontend tool that runs completely locally in your browser. You select your preferences via a simple form.
whatIs.prec3: We convert your input into a perfectly structured text that the AI understands optimally.
whatIs.ai1: No more standard routes, but 100% individualized.
whatIs.ai2: Takes vehicle dimensions, budget, and preferences into account.
whatIs.ai3: Saves you from tedious typing and clarifying with the AI.

diff.q: Prompt vs. Direct AI ‚Äì what's the difference?
diff.title: The choice is yours: copy for free or generate directly in the app.
diff.gen1: At the end you receive a finished text prompt.
diff.gen2: Simply copy it and paste it into ChatGPT, Claude or Gemini.
diff.gen3: Free of charge and you use your existing AI account.
diff.gen4: Full control over the subsequent chat.
diff.ai: Mode: Use AI Directly (API Key needed)
diff.ai1: The route is generated and displayed directly in our app.
diff.ai2: No copying back and forth between different tabs.
diff.ai4: You need your own API key from your AI provider.

howItWorks.q: How exactly does the planning work?
howItWorks.title: To your perfect itinerary in just a few steps.
howItWorks.step1a: Set start, destination, duration and max daily kilometers.
howItWorks.step2a: Enter vehicle dimensions, weight class, vehicle type, and your self‚Äësufficiency setup (solar, house battery, autonomy days).
howItWorks.step3a: Copy prompt (and paste manually into ChatGPT etc) OR enter your own API key to show the route directly in the app.

cost.q: Is it really free to use?
cost.title: Yes, Camping Route is a free open-source project.
cost.free1: Using the form and prompt generation is 100% free.
cost.free2: No registration, no database, no backend.
cost.transDesc: Only if you want to 'Use AI directly', you enter your OWN API key. You pay the minimal API usage fees (usually a few cents per route) directly to your AI provider (OpenAI, Google, Mistral). We as an app have nothing to do with this, earn nothing from it, and do not cover API costs!

privacy.q: What happens to my entered data?
privacy.title: Your data stays on your device.
privacy.device1: We have no backend and no database! If you enable saving, your inputs (excluding API keys) are stored locally on your device for 30 days.
privacy.sec1: Your data only leaves your device if you send it directly to the API of the chosen AI provider.

aiModel.q: Which AI model should I choose?
aiModel.title: Each model has its own strengths in route planning.
aiModel.gemini1: Extremely good with current places, pitches, and POIs as it uses Google's massive database. Often generates the most realistic and beautiful routes for Europe.
aiModel.gpt1: Logically unbeatable. Strictly adheres to constraints like max daily kilometers and budgets. The text output of version 5.2 is highly structured and extremely detailed.
aiModel.mistral1: A strong European model. Works very fast and offers excellent value for money (the API is often cheaper than OpenAI).
aiModel.recDesc: Tip: For the best campsite recommendations and scenic highlights, we currently recommend Google Gemini.

save.title: Save inputs locally
save.desc: Stores your form inputs on this device for 30 days. Use ‚ÄúClear data‚Äù to remove the saved data from this device.
save.coffeeHint: CampingRoute.app is open-source and ad-free ‚Äî your support helps with server and development costs. Thank you!

disclaimer.description1: As a service provider, we are responsible for our own content on these pages according to ¬ß 7 Abs.1 TMG. The generated motorhome routes are created by external Artificial Intelligence (such as OpenAI or Gemini). We assume no liability or guarantee for the accuracy, feasibility, or safety of the suggested routes and overnight stops. Using these routes is strictly at the driver's own risk and responsibility.
disclaimer.description2: Our service contains links to external third-party websites. We have no influence on their content and therefore cannot assume any liability for these external contents.

openSource.title: Copyright & Open Source
openSource.description1: The content and works created by the site operators on these pages are subject to the MIT License. The project is open-source. You can view, modify, and use the source code on GitHub.

general.title: General Data Processing
general.description: Protecting your data is very important to us. CampingRoute.app is designed as a pure client-side application. This means we do not operate databases or create user accounts. All data you enter remains primarily in your browser.

local.title: Local Storage
local.description: If you enable local saving, your form inputs and settings (e.g., chosen language) are stored only in your browser and are automatically deleted after 30 days. API keys are never stored. This data is never transmitted to our servers.

ai.title: AI Integration (OpenAI, Gemini, Mistral)
ai.description: If you use direct AI generation, your form data (start, destination, vehicle, preferences) is converted into text (prompt) and sent directly to your chosen AI provider (OpenAI, Google Gemini, or Mistral AI) using your own API key. We do not store this traffic or log API keys. The privacy policies of the AI provider you use apply.

sidebar.description: CampingRoute.app does not use tracking cookies that require consent (like Google Analytics, Meta Pixel, etc.). We do not use any mechanisms to analyze your user behavior.

noTracking.description: Only essential, technically necessary information for the React app to function (e.g. for multi-language support via i18next) is kept locally in the browser.

rights.title: Your Rights
rights.description: Since we do not store personal data on our servers, the traditional right to deletion or information requests from us does not apply. You have full control over your data at all times: to remove all settings saved by CampingRoute.app, simply clear your browser data (Local Storage) for this website.

hosting.title: Hosting
hosting.description: This website is hosted on a cloud server provided by Hetzner Online GmbH. When accessing this site, the hosting provider automatically collects access data (server log files) such as IP address, browser used, and time of access. This data is only used for the secure operation of the servers and is not merged with other data sources.

prompt.systemRole: You are a professional motorhome route planner with specialized knowledge of Germany and international travel destinations. Create a practical, well-structured motorhome route based on my specifications. Consider vehicle specifications, travel destinations, budget requirements, and personal preferences. If real-time data (e.g., traffic, availability, exact prices) is not available, work with plausible estimates, mark them as such, and indicate what I should check myself in the navigation system or a camping app.

labels.budgetNote: Budget is the hard ceiling; budget level is the quality preference within that limit.
labels.travelPaceNote: soft preference, max km/day has priority

prompt.instructions:
Plan the route with the parameters mentioned above and structure your response into modules with clear headings. Do not use asterisks (*) or double asterisks (**) in the response.

1. Stage Planning (Daily kilometers, driving time, breaks every 2-3 hours, alternative routes if applicable, and brief justification).

2. Overnight Stays (Specific campsites/pitches and alternatives with brief descriptions; include the official website, address, and phone number if available. Links are very important and should usually exist. Always write full links with https:// (e.g., https://example.com). Always write full links with https:// (e.g., https://example.com). Include approximate price ranges, but mark prices as estimates. Always find at least one alternative per overnight stay with the same details.)

3. Highlights & Activities (Top 3 per stage, briefly with costs/opening hours if known).

4. Practical Tips (Navigation, waste disposal, emergency information).

5. Best Travel Time & Duration (Brief section).

6. Services on the Road (Fuel, supermarkets, workshops).

7. Additional Info (Budget guidance, sustainability, health, connectivity).

8. Technology & Equipment (Short checklist, app recommendations).

9. Flexibility (Alternative routes, legal notes on wild camping, tools for further optimization).

Important: Use your internal map knowledge, if available, to roughly calculate distances and typical driving times between stages. Provide distances in km and driving times in hours/minutes, and mark them as estimates (e.g., "approx. 230 km / 3:00-3:30 h"). Avoid exact precision if you do not have access to current routing data, and explicitly ask me to verify the route in the navigation system (e.g., Google Maps, Here, Garmin, OpenStreetMap app).

If your platform offers a file download, always save the GPX file with the .gpx extension (not .txt). If no download is possible, output only the GPX file, without any extra text or markers. Also provide a short download guide for macOS, iOS, Windows, and Android.

gpx.garmin:
GPX file: Append exactly one GPX file for Garmin waypoints at the end of the response.

Important: Output the GPX as a plain XML block, without Markdown, without backticks, and without additional markers like BEGIN/END.

<gpx version="1.1" creator="CampingRoute.app" xmlns="http://www.topografix.com/GPX/1/1">
  ...
</gpx>

Requirements:
Create <wpt> waypoints for start, all stages, overnight stays, and destination. For overnight stays, include address, website, and phone (if available) in <desc>. Alternatives (mandatory) must be listed only in <desc> with name, address, website, and phone (if available).
Do not output a route (<rte>) or a track (<trk>).

After the normal response sections, output only the GPX block with no extra text outside it.
gpx.routeTrack:
GPX file: Append exactly one GPX file (route+track) at the end of the response.

Important: Output the GPX as a plain XML block, without Markdown, without backticks, and without additional markers like BEGIN/END.

<gpx version="1.1" creator="CampingRoute.app" xmlns="http://www.topografix.com/GPX/1/1">
  ...
</gpx>

Requirements:
Create <wpt> waypoints for start, all stages, overnight stays, and destination. For overnight stays, include address, website, and phone (if available) in <desc>. Alternatives (mandatory) must be listed only in <desc> with name, address, website, and phone (if available).
Create a route (<rte>) with all points in order (<rtept>) so Garmin recognizes it as a route.
Also create the full route as a track (<trk> with <trkseg> and <trkpt>).

After the normal response sections, output only the GPX block with no extra text outside it.

GPX file: Append two GPX files at the end of the response.

Important: Each GPX block must be plain XML, without Markdown, without backticks, and without additional markers like BEGIN/END.

  ...
</gpx>

Block 2 (GPX route+track):

</gpx>

Do not output a route (<rte>) or a track (<trk>).

Create a route (<rte>) with all points in order (<rtept>) so Garmin recognizes it as a route.
